The **Speaker of the Lok Sabha** is the presiding officer of the [Lok
Sabha](/wiki/Lok_Sabha "Lok Sabha"),[1] the [lower house](/wiki/Lower_house
"Lower house") of the [Parliament of India](/wiki/Parliament_of_India
"Parliament of India"). The speaker is elected in the very first meeting of
the Lok Sabha following general elections. Serving for a term of five years,
the Speaker chosen from amongst the members of the Lok Sabha, and is by
convention a member of the ruling party or alliance.

The current speaker is [Sumitra Mahajan](/wiki/Sumitra_Mahajan "Sumitra
Mahajan") of the [Bharatiya Janata Party](/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party
"Bharatiya Janata Party"), who is presiding over the [16th Lok
Sabha](/wiki/16th_Lok_Sabha "16th Lok Sabha"). She is the second woman to hold
the office, after her immediate predecessor [Meira Kumar](/wiki/Meira_Kumar
"Meira Kumar").[2]

## Powers and functions of the
Speaker[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Speaker_of_the_Lok_Sabha&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Powers and functions of the Speaker")]

The Speaker of the Lok Sabha conducts the business in house; and decides
whether a bill is a [money bill](/wiki/Money_bill "Money bill") or not. They
maintain discipline and decorum in the house and can punish a member for their
unruly behaviour by suspending them. They also permit the moving of various
kinds of motions and resolutions such as a [motion of no
confidence](/wiki/Motion_of_no_confidence "Motion of no confidence"), [motion
of adjournment](/wiki/Adjournment_debate "Adjournment debate"), [motion of
censure](/wiki/Motion_of_censure "Motion of censure") and calling attention
notice as per the rules. The Speaker decides on the agenda to be taken up for
discussion during the meeting. The date of election of speaker is fixed by the
President. Further, all comments and speeches made by members of the House are
addressed to the speaker. The speaker also presides over the joint sitting of
both Houses of Parliament. The counterpart of the Speaker in the Rajya Sabha
is the Chairman, who is the Vice President of India. In the [warrant of
precedence](/wiki/Indian_order_of_precedence "Indian order of precedence"),
the speaker of Lok Sabha comes next only to The Deputy Prime Minister of
India. Speaker has the sixth rank in the political executive of India

## Removal of the
Speaker[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Speaker_of_the_Lok_Sabha&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Removal of the Speaker")]

Speaker can be removed by the Lok Sabha by a resolution passed by an effective
majority of the House as per [Articles 94 and
96](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_India/Part_V
"s:Constitution of India/Part V").

Speaker is also removed on getting disqualified for being [Lok
Sabha](/wiki/Lok_Sabha "Lok Sabha") member under sections 7 & 8 of
[Representation of the People Act,
1951](/wiki/Representation_of_the_People_Act,_1951 "Representation of the
People Act, 1951").[3] This would arise out of speaker's wrong certification
of a bill as money bill inconsistent with the definition given in [Articles
110](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_India/Part_V
"s:Constitution of India/Part V") of the constitution.[4] When courts uphold
the unconstitutional act of the speaker for wrong certification of a bill as
money bill, it amounts to disrespecting the constitution deserving conviction
under [Prevention of Insults to National Honour Act,
1971](/wiki/Prevention_of_Insults_to_National_Honour_Act,_1971 "Prevention of
Insults to National Honour Act, 1971") which is applicable for
disqualification of speaker's Lok Sabha membership under section 8k of
Representation of the People Act, 1951. However the omissions in the procedure
committed by the speaker in the Lok Sabha can not be challenged in court of
law per [Article
122](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Constitution_of_India/Part_V
"s:Constitution of India/Part V")[5]

## Protem
Speaker[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Speaker_of_the_Lok_Sabha&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Protem Speaker")]

After a general election and the formation of a new government, a list of
senior Lok Sabha members prepared by the Legislative Section is submitted to
the Minister of Parliamentary Affairs, who selects a protem speaker. The
appointment has to be approved by the president.[6]

The first meeting after the election when the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker
are selected by members of the Parliament is held under the pro tem Speaker.
In absence of the Speaker, the Deputy Speaker acts as Speaker and in the
absence of both a committee of six member selected by the Speaker will act as
Speaker according to their seniority.
